<blockquote>
<p dir="auto">Basic Functionality of RS Wiki:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>New Group: creates a collection of Wiki Pages, the creator of group,<br>
and anyone they share the publish keys with) is the moderator</li>
<li>New Page: Create a new Wiki Page, only Group Moderators can do this,</li>
<li>Edit: Anyone Can Edit the Wiki Page, and the changes form a tree under the original,</li>
<li>RePublish: This is used by the Moderators to accept and reject Edits.,<br>
the republished page becomes a new version of the Root Page, allowing more edits to be done</li>
</ul>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p dir="auto">Ideas:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>Formatting: No HTML, lets use Markdown or something similar.,</li>
<li>Diffs, lots of edits will lead to complex merges - a robust merge tool is essential,</li>
<li>Read Mode... hide all the Edits, and only show the most recently published versions,</li>
<li>Easy Duplication - to take over an Abandoned or badly moderated Wiki. Copies All base versions to a new group</li>
<li>WikiLinks. A generic Wiki Cross Linking system. This should be combined with Easy Duplication option,<br>
to allow easy replacement of groups if necessary... A good design here is critical to a successful Wiki ecosystem,</li>
<li>work out how to include media (photos, audio, video, etc) without embedding in pages,<br>
this would leverage the turtle transfer system somehow - maybe like channels.,</li>
<li>Comments, reviews etc can be incorporated - ideas here are welcome.,</li>
</ul>
</blockquote>

NewMarkdownViewer-module__safe-html-box--dKCgP"><p dir="auto">As far as I can see, wiki authentication flags are the same as channel, meaning that: group modifications (admin level), and new messages require the publish key, whereas child messages (e.g. edits or comments) don't. In particular the moderator list cannot be different that the list of people who can post root messages. Is that intended?</p>
<p dir="auto">This doesn't look like a very practical solution to me because sharing publish rights cannot be revoked whereas you may want to remove a moderator. Also post editing needs to be validated everywhere in the network and not everybody knows who owns the publish rights.</p>
<p dir="auto">With this, moderation can be done like in forums by a admin-level list of GxsIds that in independent from publish rights:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>the admin edits the group data to allow/remove moderators</li>
<li>moderators can edit any existing message (not only their own). When removing a moderator it is kept on the list with a termination date.</li>
<li>at any point in the validation process (meaning everywhere in the network) edits that do not respect the moderation rule (non self-edited message by someone not in the moderator or edition date doesn't meet the moderation list) list will be discarded.</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto">Some question remain: how do we mitigate the risk of wiki data being corrupted by trolls?</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>require publish rights for child-messages? (this is not very practical for the same reasons as above)</li>
<li>in addition to the moderator list, include in the group data (admin-controlled) a publish list that only allows some users to publish? (this way we can easily remove someone who corrupts the pages)? That seems the right way to go. This way we can force a contact author for the wiki (flag GRP_OPTION_AUTHEN_AUTHOR_SIGN) and let that person add/remove editors.</li>
</ul>

data-turbolinks="false"><div class="Box-sc-62in7e-0 markdown-body NewMarkdownViewer-module__safe-html-box--dKCgP"><blockquote>
<p dir="auto">As far as I can see, wiki authentication flags are the same as channel, meaning that: group modifications (admin level), and new messages require the publish key, whereas child messages (e.g. edits or comments) don't. In particular the moderator list cannot be different that the list of people who can post root messages. Is that intended?</p>
<p dir="auto">This doesn't look like a very practical solution to me because sharing publish rights cannot be revoked whereas you may want to remove a moderator. Also post editing needs to be validated everywhere in the network and not everybody knows who owns the publish rights.</p>
<p dir="auto">With this, moderation can be done like in forums by a admin-level list of GxsIds that in independent from publish rights:</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>the admin edits the group data to allow/remove moderators</li>
<li>moderators can edit any existing message (not only their own). When removing a moderator it is kept on the list with a termination date.</li>
<li>at any point in the validation process (meaning everywhere in the network) edits that do not respect the moderation rule (non self-edited message by someone not in the moderator or edition date doesn't meet the moderation list) list will be discarded.</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto">Some question remain: how do we mitigate the risk of wiki data being corrupted by trolls?</p>
<ul dir="auto">
<li>require publish rights for child-messages? (this is not very practical for the same reasons as above)</li>
<li>in addition to the moderator list, include in the group data (admin-controlled) a publish list that only allows some users to publish? (this way we can easily remove someone who corrupts the pages)? That seems the right way to go. This way we can force a contact author for the wiki (flag GRP_OPTION_AUTHEN_AUTHOR_SIGN) and let that person add/remove editors.</li>
</ul>
<p dir="auto">Any comments about this?</p>
</blockquote>
<p dir="auto">This is a very valid matter, and I agree the current wiki auth model (sharing publish rights = moderation) is quite limiting and hard to revoke safely.</p>
<p dir="auto">That said, this feels like a broader <strong>architectural change</strong> (new moderator model, validation rules, GUI, migration) rather than part of the current wiki modernization todos.</p>
<p dir="auto">I’d suggest opening a <strong>separate issue</strong> to track this moderator/auth redesign properly, so the current PRs can stay focused on completing the listed todos. I’d be happy to follow or contribute to that discussion separately.</p></div></div><div role="toolbar" aria-label="Reactions" class="d-flex gap-1 flex-wrap"><button data-component="IconButton" This reverts commit f1a581f60aab4dc5c6b50190711986f528ed0c1c.

The channel-style publish key sharing is NOT appropriate for Wiki.
Wiki requires a forums-style moderator implementation that's
independent from publish rights, as discussed in issue #3107.

Todo 6 remains pending and requires:
- Admin-controlled moderator list (separate from publish rights)
- Validation logic for moderator permissions
- GUI for moderator management
- This is a significant architectural change beyond current scope

.suggest-icon svg, .suggest-icon path { fill: rgb(255, 255, 255); }

.suggest-icon svg::before, .suggest-icon path::before { bottom: -6px; left: -4px; background-color: rgb(158, 123, 255); }

.suggest-icon svg::after, .suggest-icon path::after { top: -5px; right: -5px; width: 5px; height: 5px; background-color: rgb(108, 132, 233); }

.suggest-icon .suggest-icon-bubble { position: absolute; width: 6px; height: 6px; background-color: rgb(108, 132, 233); border-radius: 50%; }

.suggest-icon .suggest-icon-bubble:nth-of-type(2n) { width: 4px; height: 4px; background-color: rgb(158, 123, 255); }

.suggest-icon .suggest-icon-bubble:nth-of-type(1) { bottom: -7px; left: -7px; }

.suggest-icon .suggest-icon-bubble:nth-of-type(2) { top: -4px; right: var(--base-size-4); }
